availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Verso of manuscript leaf is a letter from Albert B. Ohs

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: converted to camel case, revised, edited

lg.head: Song of the Redwood Tree
lg.l: A California song

A prophesy & indirection—a thought im-
palpable to breathe as air

l.add: A chorus of dryad's, boding, departing—or hamad'dryads departing;

lg.l:
A grant voice but not in words—a mur-
muring,
dying
fateful
voice, out of the earth
& air,

Voice ofa mighty dying, tree in the redwood
forest dense.

l.hi: Farewell? ye brethren, *mdash;farewell

lg.l:
Farewell,
Farewell
O earth & sky—farewell

neighboring
waters

has come.

div1.p: idea(very likely a kink)that the forehead may be made to look as much like a splash of light as will be consistent with all else—and without the intention being too evident—

—As I also told you I don't will be satisfied with ofvery little work on the the outside of the picture, but want your own touch, spirit, freedom truth freedom & style on the head & especially the central part thereof—though I suppose the whole hangs together—
